pages.text: Terrestrisuchus gracilis comes from the Upper Triassic, with fossils being found in the Pant-y-ffynon and Ruthin Quarries, Wales (United Kingdom); Tytherington and Cromhall Quarries, England (United Kingdom). It is a small crocodylomorph, growing to 76 cm cm in length, with a possible length of 1 m or more. Unlike modern crocodiles, Terrestrisuchus lived entirely on land, and as such also hand long limbs that were held beneath their bodies,

as well as also having its eyes being supported by a sclerotic ring. The generic name derives from the Latin word 'terrestris', to mean 'terrestrial'; and 'suchus', to mean 'crocodile'. The specific name derives directly from the Latin word 'gracilis', to mean 'slender'.
